Pros:

Cons: None that I can think of

Pros:
Amazing benefits
Logistics Departments flow well together
Lab departments flow well together

Review Title: Getting worse by the day at NAIC1
Pros: The people below leadership level are amazing.
Cons:
It's become just like any other warehouse job. Underpaid and overworked. They give you inadequate support and resources to do your job and you will have to improvise most of the time. This is highly technical work which you are expected to execute perfectly, but with little to no support. Managers will only promote their friends and family instead of people who are actually qualified. Leadership sits at their desks all day long and refuses to actually help. None of them could even help if they wanted because they all were hired from outside the company and don't know how to do anything job related. Favoritism is the foundation of leadership at NAIC1. They ship people they don't like to other buildings with at most 2 days' notice, so be prepared to adjust your childcare and educational schedule in the blink of an eye.

They police the floor and micromanage everyone out of the door. All of the tenured and talented employees have either quit or on the way out. The project manager is clueless and only comes around when it's time to complain about something. The last time I saw him, he walked around the floor upset that people weren't paying attention to him and we all got reprimanded for it.

We used to be treated like actual human beings. We are now treated like robots. Just parts of the dying machine. If you work here, just remember, you are replaceable and you mean nothing to this company.

Pros: The people at WWT all care about the company's overall success. There are some talented and intelligent technical resources, as well as competent and experienced sales teams that operate with integrity and a desire to help customers succeed. The pay is good, it is privately held so no stock awards, but they make up for it with great benefits.
Cons:
Growing rapidly with silos from that expansion. 
Heavily rely on partners to support marketing and brand awareness, and miss out on opportunities to share more publically about what all WWT does and is good at.

Pros: Healthcare, LOA and PTO benefits offered by WWT are outstanding. They are working to provide better training to new employees. They genuinely care about their employees.
Cons: The company is growing so quickly, they don't have enough processes documented. Which means for some positions, people's work shows inconsistent quality. With a lack of processes, it can be difficult for a new person to learn.

Pros:
My paycheck was always correct.
They offer adequate PTO. 
Education reimbursement.
They offer every program available for free on Udemy.
Cons: Their pay is absolutely far to low for the level of knowledge they expect you to aquire and utilize. They say that the benefits they offer make up the difference. I have looked into that statement, it really doesn't put them anywhere close to the pay every other warehouse is offering. I made less than $18/hr after 5 years of employment. They also preach about how there are possibilities everywhere for growth. Unfortunately, I've only ever seen people who were connected to individuals with pull get any job that can be considered an upgrade.

Pros: Great People to work with
Cons: Career movement, can get stuck in your silo

Pros: Good culture, good pay, great work-life balance
Cons: Projects aren't as exciting as other strategy consulting firms. They are heavy on the tech implementation side.

Pros: good leadership. good work life balance
Cons: pay is based on personality, not skill or contribution level.

Review Title: Core values don't apply to equally
Pros: Very generous health benefits, Great people
Cons: Executive team not honest with themselves or their people. Little to no diversity at the executive and Sr. leadership level

Pros: Great culture, innovative work, and clear leadership direction.
Cons: Salaries as you are promoted within do not always match market.

Review Title: Not actually a great place to work
Pros: Good Healthcare, but they'll make sure to mention that they pay a lot for it every open-enrollment
Cons:
Poor raises. 

Poor bonuses.

Silent Layoffs two years in a row.

Cult-like mentality amongst both company leaders and lower org leaders. 

They claim to be a tech company but don't have the stomach to "do whatever it takes" to succeed in being a great place to work.

More interested in penny-pinching what they pay their people (and what country they hire from) than actually winning customers on quality and innovation.

They harp on innovation but don't actually have the appetite to support innovative work within the company.

Pros: Company has excellent culture, takes care of employees, profit sharing , excellent benefits
Cons: Can’t think of any at this time

Pros: The culture at WWT cannot be beat. I would not want to work anywhere else. I love the people on our team and am given flexibility and direction.
Cons: Our team is growing and changing every day, which can lead to ambiguity in the role. There aren't many cons but I would say that it is sometimes challenging to find an answer. You have to be self-motivated and unafraid to dig to discover an answer or resolution.

Review Title: DEI and favoritism is a bad mix!
Pros: Great pay! Great benefits! Great work life balance. Opportunities to learn new technologies.
Cons: Way too much favoritism! WWT leadership talks a big game of DEI, but you're only inclusive if you are part of the upper mgmt good Ole boy system. Some get promos and notoriety while others do not. Advancement is something reserved for workers in their favor. Also discrimination runs rampant. You can be discredited and blackballed for being sick. Highly illegal!!

Pros: Exciting opportunities, great customers and innovative partner ecosystem. Exec and leadership commitment to values, culture and engagement is off the charts good.
Cons: Amazing growth creates some challenges and confusion on ownership and consistency across different teams.

Pros: Company provides a competitive salary
Cons: There is very little work/life balance.

Review Title: Clear direction and engagement from the top down
Pros: Pay, culture, benefits, inclusion, leadership
Cons: I can’t find a single negative to say about working at WWT

Pros: Great capabilities to offer customers. Great people throughout WWT. Great benefits Great facilities
Cons: The executive team tends to be insular and difficult to crack into for those outside of STL and the various familial/friendship ties. Titles and promotions are inconsistently applied in the organization. Too many silos internally; WWT is getting too big to let various groups do whatever they want and politics are much worse today than years ago when I joined. Pay is low relative to peers. Travel restrictions. Diversity initiatives, while well intentioned aren't working well. Too many undeserved promotions; promoting based on diverse gender/race is no better than doing the same for someone part of the majority. Promote based on performance.

Pros: good work environment with decent pay and great benefits
Cons: Culture and my building has steadily declined over the years lack of transparency from upper management.

Pros: Great culture, amazing services, customer focused
Cons: Challenging market landscape with budgets being cut and competition growing

Pros: Good work life balance. Great culture, great team
Cons: Lack of pay range transparency

Pros: Nice office space and good healthcare
Cons:
Pretty much everything else 
- pay was well below market rate. They say they benchmark against the market, but they give raises of 1-2% and when I left the company, I had been searching for a while and had gotten 5 different offers over the course of my year's job search and ALL of them were paying 25-35% higher than WWT. 
- very nepotistic, boys club mentality. High bonuses for execs of millions of dollars while refusing to give raises to the majority of employees that even keep up with the rate of inflation. 
- do not invest in resources. While I was working at WWT in the corporate Maryland heights office, the company won a large contract and didn't properly staff the warehouse to accommodate the shipments. Corporate execs then proceeded to shame the employees at the Maryland heights office to work their 8-5 desk job, then go work a shift at the warehouse in edwardsville from 6pm-11pm to pack boxes because they didn't hire enough workers. This was for no pay or benefit and they called it "volunteering" to fulfill a many-millions dollar contract that WWT was getting paid for. When people didn't sign up to "volunteer," management accused people I worked with of not being team players. 
- the company spends money on very showy events like their Global Sales Meeting, where they fly out 1500 people from various sales/sales support positions to somewhere like Vegas to stay at a hotel like the Cosmo. Employees are forced to go, but then forced to SHARE ROOMS with coworkers. I knew people that had to share a hotel room with their bosses. No option was given to not attend the conference, and if you wanted to not share a room with a coworker/boss, WWT forced you to pay for your own accommodations. Very inappropriate and weird, especially since the bathrooms at the Cosmo have windows into the hotel room, so to shower, you had to coordinate a time with your roommate so they wouldn't be in the room while you showered and still would fear that they would walk into the hotel room and see you showering. The company spends money on things that don't matter while skimping on things like basic accommodations for a mandated work trip.

overall, this company does not have its priorities in line and needs to prioritize its employees rather than ONLY profit.

Review Title: Not a great place to work
Pros:
They have some of the best talent that can be found around St. Louis.
It is a great place to hone your skills for your next opportunity.
Excellent medical.
Cons:
Management expects cult like behavior. 
They berate employees into filling out the survey that qualifies them as a great place to work.
No clear path to grow.
Pay is below average.
They claim to care about their customers when laying off individuals with critical knowledge on projects.

Pros: Great place to work; great leadership at the top; passion for partnering with customers
Cons: Just your every company growing pains, but always improving

Review Title: Culture has eroded in recent years
Pros: Good health insurance and remote work policy.
Cons: Company is unable or unwilling to focus on engineering consulting service offerings, so anyone working in this branch of WWT is at extreme risk of sudden RIF when quarterly numbers don't look great.

Review Title: Really is a great place to work
Pros: Very positive work environment, growing company, a lot of opportunity for growth, benefits are amazing
Cons: Company is growing fast, so there are growing pains along the way.

Pros: The benefits have gone down hill every year, but they are mostly company paid, so you can't even complain. They do this on purpose. If your local to STL, you gain more benefits with this. For my position, pay was good. As a whole, the company doesn't pay well and relies on cheaper labor. Some good and friendly people at the ground floor levels. It's when you get closer to corporate that it's true colors show.
Cons: The have and the have nots. I have been to STL a few times and met many good workers in the warehouses. It's factory work for the most part, but they will be incredibly jealous of you for travel and pay after you start talking to them. It's a mixed bag. They heavily rely upon being black owned, yet in four years, I never saw the "founder" nor heard his name until BLM and Juneteenth came around. You would be surprised to know he existed at all, but they promote the heck out of it now. It doesn't really matter. WWT has a cult like following internally, until you begin to see the cracks in the foundation. Silicon Valley of STL, never quite worked out. They waste a heck of a lot of money on the if you build it motto. It's a cut throat world, and WWT will burn anyone who jumps in their way.

Pros: Challenging and creative work when they can justify their price to the client
Cons: Intent to increase the workforce to be higher international presence by laying off US workforce

Pros:
Fantastic Leadership
Work life balance
Amazing benefits
Cons: None that I can think of

Pros: There is a ton about WWT to love. This is a great place to work. Good people and a company that will challenge you.
Cons: They talk about the culture, The Path, but leadership doesn't live up to the culture anymore. It has morphed into something different.

Pros: Collaborative amongst teams across company
Cons: Updating division names or group orgs can make it hard to keep up changes.

Review Title: Overall a great org, but pay is woefully missing from the larger conversation
Pros: WWT has some of the best people you could ask to work with. The health benefits are good, and management has embraced the workplace flexibility technology creates.
Cons: Workers are getting absolutely crushed on several economic fronts. For a company that boasts revenue in the several billions, providing salary increases that are at least 6-10% (at the very least) is not asking for much. Unfortunately, no amount of culture initiatives or “perks” can outweigh the sheer stress and uncertainty your workers experience when they are struggling to make ends meet through no fault of their own. There is more than enough money to pay your workers more, retain solid benefits and continue operating as a profitable company.

Pros: Overall the company is really good. Especially for the IT/Office side.
Cons: Supply chain is lacking alot. Supervisors get their hands tied behind their back by managers. Executive management below the Jeree level doesn't make an effort on the floor, they barely walk around and really only know the best/worst workers by name/face. They don't really communicate with the other 95% of the work force. When they do walk the floor it's almost like they're subjecting themselves to something below them. Body language speaks alot about them. Not every NAIC/Program is equal. You can have awesome leadership in one area but terrible in another. Executive team should shadow their leaders more consistently to find where the supervisors/managers are lacking. The office/IT part of the company is treated differently than supply chain. I know this from GROW and communicating with them. Their leaders issues are nowhere near the leaders issues in supply chain and they always act shocked when we discuss that.

Pros: Great place to work foreal!
Cons: Needs to pay sales ops more!

Pros:
Great resume builder for interns looking to gain professional experience.
Flexible schedule
Great mentors
Cons: Lack of creative jobs available.

Pros: Good benefits and good people
Cons: Pay range isn’t the best

Pros: Professional Autonomy is nice, we are not micromanaged Overall day to day operations are run well within Project Engineering
Cons: Pay range is quite low, they have reduced the pay ceiling on a number of Project Engineering jobs as well. Each position within my department had their ceiling dropped by 10-20k. Pay raises not well defined but seem to be getting better? Normally it is just a flat 3% without wiggle room regardless of performance, though this seems to be improving somewhat. Only 1 year has been performance based so far, lets hope this is a trend. There are two companies at WWT. The warehouses/lab, and then the offices. They have -vastly- different cultures, with warehouse/lab being treated only as an expense not a value driver. Lack of a professional certification program, this is in the works, but has been for over 2 years. At some point it just becomes more "wait and you'll see!"

Pros: Fantastic culture, benefits and growth.
Cons: High level of performance expected.

Review Title: The Best Employer I've ever worked for..
Pros: WWT has always made its people a priority and it shows. The benefits are outstanding, management is always actively seeking out how they can be better. In my 1.5 years here so far, I have seen the company take action on so many suggestions and employee feedback. They truly listen and are doing all that they can to be a top employer.
Cons: In non sales roles it can be difficult to achieve a salary at or above market rate. If you can find a way to achieve the $$ you want through bonuses and other options, there is potentially other ways to get to where you want to be, but it can be a challenge. You should look to factor in yearly raises as well, and see that you can build to market rate and beyond within a few years. The benefits are well worth the hit to the pay, especially if you are looking to have or start a family.

Pros: Good leadership in general and good benefits
Cons: Tied to the work that is brought in, whether it fits your interests or not

Pros: I have enjoyed working for world wide every day I come to work. There truly hasn't been a "Bad" day on the job. The benefits are unmatched here, no more than $25/mo for a single person being insured medically.
Cons: Starting in the warehouse can be a challenge. Once you move past that you will truly see how awesome this company is to work for.

Review Title: Not sure who they want to be
Pros: Good compensation. Great benefit ideology.
Cons: WWT is a solid company on firm financial footing. However, each time they say they want to get less-transactional and more strategic, they throw up all over themselves. Uncovering wedges to pursue on large solicitations takes vision and strategy. They're still stuck in the, "We can't do that" phase. Also a very nepotism based culture. They don't even pretend to hide it. Be careful.

Review Title: Excellent Company - Great Leadership and Great Culture
Pros: Great Culture - People First!
Cons: Nothing major to report on the cons.

Pros: Great culture is constantly reinforced and work is being done to address a remote workforce. Executive Leadership is very accessible and offers many opportunities for you to provide feedback that is thoughtfully considered. There is a focus on training for anyone who seeks out opportunities and takes advantage of them. Flexible, remote working with the opportunity to get together in person allows for collaboration while still offering the ability to work without distraction. Executive Leadership is transparent with employees on both successes and challenges and has a high level of consistency in the mission and vision. The focus on Diversity and Inclusion feels genuine and is really just an extension of an already good program. Coworkers truly make this a great place to work.
Cons: Explosive growth has created operational silos. With such a high number of remote workers, the camaraderie and culture is harder to maintain to the same levels as before. Work life balance can be a challenge depending on your role.

Review Title: Good company but lots of competition
Pros: Strong culture to get things done on your own.

Pros: uhhh nothing really yea no
Cons: Working at a certain technology company was an absolute nightmare. The toxic work culture, excessive workload, poor leadership, lack of career growth opportunities, inadequate compensation and benefits, and outdated technology and infrastructure made it an unbearable place to work. The company claimed to value teamwork and collaboration, but it was all a facade as employees were pitted against each other in a cutthroat competition. The workload was overwhelming, with tight deadlines and unrealistic expectations, leading to burnout. The leadership was disconnected and ineffective, while career growth opportunities were limited. The compensation and benefits were subpar, considering the demands of the job, and the technology and infrastructure were outdated. Overall, it was a dreadful employment experience that should be avoided at all costs.

Review Title: The worse employer I have ever had the displeasure to work for!
Pros: When you don’t have to interface with management (managers, directors, VP’s, etc), great peers and colleagues.
Cons: Where do I start….I came to WWT because they had a minority owner in David Steward. I, for some reason, thought this would be a racially diverse company, from management to the engineering staff, with a plethora of opportunities to advance your career; however, I was completely wrong! There were things that were done to me over the course of 6-8 months of my tenure at WWT that were unbelievable. I was accused of aggressive behavior racially synonymous with a certain minority group. I was accused of unprofessional behavior by certain account teams and management despite their being no evidence to support these assertions. Management was unsupportive despite there being plenty of evidence to support my claims of what I was experiencing as racial microaggressions. Management loved the terms, “coach them up,” and “right seat on the bus,” which only applies to the majority. There’s so much I dealt with in my short tenure at WWT, and despite being technically “laid-off,” I declined the severance out of principle. I wanted nothing from a company that treats minorities in the way I, and others were treated. I was offered a couple options, #1 was totally disrespectful and not really an option, and #2 was resignation with severance, I chose neither. I’m extremely blessed to no longer be at WWT. The stress from this situation added 5 years to my life that I can’t get back. I’ll leave with this final note, I only experienced these issues within a certain group at WWT. I’m not sure how the rest of the company is/was, but under the conditions I described, I’m glad I didn’t stick around to find out. These are my opinions derived through my experiences with the company. The great thing is that I have all of this well documented. I started capturing it early on in the process as part of my own professional therapy session. I’m not sure what I’ll do with the information, but I will show it to my children as they need to know what to expect when they enter corporate America.

Pros: Great benefits, good culture, mostly remote.
Cons: Hard to get the pay you want.

Pros: In the short time I’ve been here there is clearly a strong team culture focused on achieving results. Unlike other tech companies, there’s a lot more understanding and patience for folks to learn from their mistakes and get support to do better. One thing that will
Cons: It’s a bit scary how much the company relies on power point and spreadsheets for a lot of internal processes. It feels a bit inefficient but building strong relationships across the firms help counteract that.

Pros: Great people Great work/life balance Fully remote Great benefits
Cons: Compensation is the only con other than that everything is great here. It truly is a great place to work

Pros: work life balance, great benefits, friendly environment,
Cons: layback, silos, lots of talking but lacking the ability to execute

Pros: Worldwide typically hires with their core values in my so when people come on board it’s like a big family because we all share the same values
Cons: It can be hard to move around and get promoted, because typically people don’t move from their current positions

Pros: Great people, culture, benefits and flexibility
Cons: Technical (systems and process) knowledge is expected at all levels

Review Title: A stepping stone but not a fantastic entry point
Pros: Good upward mobility if you can get into a technology position Decent Benefits The best managers I've ever had are in their data center department Fantastic training options Decent networking opportunities
Cons: -It's incredibly difficult to go anywhere if you start in any warehouse location -A lot of the warehouses have extremely poor management -very difficult to utilize the training opportunities at the lowest level due to being in a production role.

Review Title: Unfortunately an Old Boys Network for a majority Boack owned company
Pros: Great culture, helpful Engineers and staff. Great healthcare and training. Excellent projects and work
Cons: Majority of those in upper management are of the same type. They bring their own and promote only certain types. Moving up REGARDLESS of how great an Engineer or leader you are, is difficult. Meritocracy did not apply for some. WWT was not always like this; I was there long enough to see this ugly transformation. Sad because Jim and Dave are nice people BUT I cannot say the same for the managers. You would never know it was a majority Black owned company. Sad and discouraging. Forgot all the stuff about Great Place to Work. It is pushed for PR reasons . May be great for the Old Boys Network

Review Title: Lots of variability and customization, which is good and bad
Pros: Great leadership at VP+ levels; brilliant peers doing good work; great work life balance; good pay and PTO
Cons: Onboarding is insufficient; your learning depends on you networking; not much transferability between programs and projects because of high customization to client needs; not much documentation and formal traning

Pros: The current health insurance plan is good.
Cons: 1) Frequent layoffs. WWT is hyper-focused on their "Great places to work" status, but only current employees are surveyed. Entire teams are often laid off without warning and without their "great employer" first attempting to relocate them elsewhere in the company or with regard to existing client contracts. This leads to a culture of uncertainty & fear, where workers are told to not to worry about the other cattle being loaded into trucks. 2) Services-oriented executive leadership is perpetually floundering. They simply don't know how to sell services, but when they do land a few deals they rapidly over-hire for those skillsets to meet anticipated future demand which never materializes, leading to a yo-yo-diet workforce. This feeds into layoffs as outlined in item #1. 3) They track every hour of your day with an internal tool requiring justification for everything. Viewed by some as micro-management is actually compensation for #2. 4) WWT thinks their "values" (the PATH) are unique in the industry, when in fact most large orgs have similar corporate mantras. What's unique is how hard WWT pushes these values in a cult-like manner, preached via weekly all-hands meetings and individual discussions with management centered around them. This is in addition to the billionaire chairman's "prosperity theology" ramblings, which may not be everyone's cup of tea.

Pros: Great Company good benefits and ok work life balance
Cons: Can be very reactive and not follow processes set in place. One team from another seem to operate in their own ways that cause disfunction at times

Review Title: Best tech culture I have ever worked in
Pros: From the executive management teams on down to individual contributors, everyone is valued and that is reflected in our success
Cons: The small company feel is being replaced by big company feel. This is inevitable and I believe is being addressed.

Pros: Insurance is decent and Some other benefits aren't the best but not the worst either.
Cons: PS is being killed off for lower quality and cheaper outsourcing burn rates. One employee at a time. Very middle management is bloated and a lot of titles are assigned to projects that are unnecessary making project costs too high.

Pros: Excellent executive leadership, good pay, good benefits, and mostly good culture.
Cons: A big company with typical big company problems including pockets of politics.

Pros: Excellent pay and benefits Great team dynamics Work from home
Cons: Retainment of employees difficult Fast paced can cause project overlook

Review Title: Siloed workaholic culture, constant change, lack of focus on execution, a risk to mental health
Pros: WWT gives the architects a lot of opportunities to get your hands involved. Lots of strategic discussions if you like that.
Cons: Too many siloes. Everyone owns "something", until they have it ripped away by some other "owner". No one actually works together. You have no power to execute change with other people who might logically work with you. Management by checklist. Quarterly partner reviews are just a dog-and-pony show - there is no effort to fix things. Partner management is all about catering to a partner, not really integrating them. It's so easy to get trapped between competing demands on your role and no one will get with you to reconcile these changes. Manager X says, "we don't do that, I'll fire you if I catch you doing that". Manager Y says, "it's your fault if this fails because you don't do that task." Managers X and Y won't ever talk to each other - you have to figure out how to tread between the two poles. As long as the partner is helping fund your compensation and the check clears, they're fine with it. No one in leadership wants to hear about problems. The approach is to "counsel" you out of believing that. There's no culture of solving a problem or changing an established practice. There are too many layers of management for such a relatively small company - I influence millions of dollars of revenue and I'm 8? levels below the CEO (and it's always churning - no one ever knows who is actually in charge). I'm working 2 full-time jobs, it feels like, with little practical support to navigate between them. I'd like to look for a different role in the company, but I'd be blocked by my current boss and the vendor management. I don't even know who I'd escalate to. There's no HR group with an open door policy. I'm too well known outside WWT that when/if I started looking around, it'd be very public. There's no "quiet" job search in my role. My mental health has severely declined in this role. I'm tired of people saying (even jokingly) that I'm going to get fired when I try to take initiative to solve things that they don't care to solve.

Pros: Great people, Work life balance, great benefits
Cons: Compensation is way behind competitors

Review Title: It really is a great place to work!
Pros: The people are amazing and the benefits are fantastic. I still love working here after 13 years.
Cons: There are definitely growing pains but we are working on it. We have grown so much through the years and the team members who were hired during COVID have not experienced the real culture. It is hard to balance all of that.

Pros:
Benefits are great
A lot of different opportunities open
Character and integrity will carry you far
Coaching up is encouraged
Cons:
Staying in the same role, no matter how great you are, will not gain you a larger raise. (A con for those who have a hard time stepping out of their comfort zones)
There are teams that have not been managed properly (mainly due to customer demands and requirements) and could use experience from other program management. Like everywhere there are the teams of yes men and minimium effort workers that seem to get promoted which brings down moral. 
This is not the case for the company as a whole, but it is where you will find majority of the problem areas. Majority of the negative reviews come from those teams' employees.

Review Title: Company Strives to be a Great Place to work for ALL
Pros: Treat employees like family and they matter, focused on employee growth as well as company growth, ALWAYS giving back to the community
Cons: Most jobs are remote so not as much personalization in getting to know other employees

Review Title: Work/Life balance is very good in this company
Pros: Work/Life balance is very good in this company
Cons: No cons working in this company
